title: Brewery owner Jaz had a risky idea. It has paid off big time
text:
The co-founder of one of Australia's most popular breweries has struck gold with a secondary endeavour: non-alcoholic beer.

Jaz Wearin and her husband Grant began Modus Operandi in 2014 on Sydney's Northern Beaches with just $7 and a dream.

Just six years later, the pair noticed the booming zero per cent market in Australia was crying out for more competition.

Jaz Wearin founded Nort in 2020. (Supplied)

They boldly entered the non-alcoholic craft beer category during the COVID-19 pandemic with the launch of Nort.

At this point, zero per cent beer was still a largely unexplored market.﻿

Now, a few years later, Nort has opened its own brewery to bump out its non-alcoholic beverages.﻿

"Since we launched in 2020, the response has been incredible," Wearon told nine.com.au.

"In the early years, demand grew explosively, so much so that we built our own 10 million-litre brewery to keep pace."

There has been a generational shift in alcohol consumption in Australia since Nort launched.

Non-alcoholic beer now accounts for 10 per cent of beer sales in Australia.

The national non-alcohol category is also expected to deliver double-digit growth by 2028, with a prediction of around 300 million litres sold that year compared to 150 million in 2024.

Wearon said Australians had been desperate for ways to stay sober and remain social.

"It really comes down to choice and balance, people want to enjoy social occasions without the downsides of alcohol all the time," she said of Nort's success.

"That might be for health, sleep, fitness, work performance, family commitments, or just wanting a clearer head the next day.

"Our slogan, 'Enjoy More', really captures that: it's not about giving up, it's about enjoying more of life without having to compromise the social experience."

Non-alcoholic beer now accounts for 10 per cent of beer sales in Australia. (Supplied)

While the Australian market is still small, Wearon is confident it will be a huge 2026 for brands in this category.

Nort is competing against the likes of Heaps Normal , Hahn, Asahi and ﻿Carlton for space on the non-alcoholic shelf.

But the home-grown brand is the little engine that could: the sales have proven this.﻿

﻿Wearon said January sales are typically several times higher than other months as New Year's resolutions kick in.

"It's very predictable now," she said of the January sales bump.

"In fact, this year we had higher demand than we forecasted, and we were literally brewing Nort up until Christmas Eve to keep up.

"Christmas and the 'silly season' brings a lot of social occasions, so people use non-alcoholic beer as a way to enjoy the moments without the downside of overindulging.

"Then in January, we see that behaviour really kick in, people deliberately choose to cut back or reset after the holidays."

Wearin said Australians are looking for ways to stay sober and remain social. (Supplied)

But sales are no longer tied to big "sober" movements like Dry July, she said.

In fact, non-alcoholic sales now mirror traditional beer sales.

"﻿What we're seeing now is that non-alc beer is mirroring the broader beer cycle, where growth isn't just tied to Dry January or Feb Fast anymore," she added.

"It's becoming ingrained in people's behaviours around the key drinking occasions like footy finals, Christmas, summer holidays, and Easter too."

title: Flight turns back twice, passenger misses best mates' wedding in QantasLink nightmare
text:
A QantasLink flight bound for the South Australian city of Port Lincoln was forced to turn around twice this morning, resulting in a six-hour delay for passengers.

The plane took off from Adelaide Airport at 7.55am but was forced to return to the tarmac almost an hour later after the aircraft hit a bird.

The flight was on the ground for an hour before the plane was given the all-clear to return to the skies, but a technical issue mid-flight forced the aircraft to turn back a second time.

A QantasLink flight bound for Port Lincoln was forced to turn around twice this morning. (9News)

"It reminded me of a Seinfeld episode," passenger Barry Stribler said.

"The second time the pilot actually came out and as we were all walking out, each individual person he apologised and said he was sorry.

"We got told that they had three other planes here so I don't understand why they wouldn't just change planes."﻿

Eventually passengers did change planes as engineers worked on the first aircraft.

The flight eventually took off just before 2pm after six hours of waiting, two delays and two different planes.

READ MORE: British band Pulp backflips on Adelaide festival withdrawal

The plane took off from Adelaide Airport at 7.55am today but was forced to return to the tarmac almost an hour later. (9News)

Imogen Evans was heading to her best friend's wedding when she was caught up in the delay.

"I'm devastated to miss the ceremony, they're two of my best friends," Evans said.

However she said there was a silver lining to the journey.

"The camaraderie on the plane has been so lovely, we've met a girl who's going to drop us straight to the wedding," she said.

A Qantas spokesperson apologised for the delay and acknowledged the frustration.

"However safety is always our first priority," the spokesperson said.

"We appreciate the patience and understanding from our customers."

title: Government dumps plans for Kimberley short stay accommodation
text:
Elizabeth Waina sits on the pavement, a debit card and a scrunched-up letter in her hand, waiting for the bank to open.

She has travelled more than 500 kilometres from her hometown of Kalumburu, Western Australia's northernmost settlement, to Kununurra, the East Kimberley's main regional hub.

Remote residents like Elizabeth Waina travel to Kununurra to access services including banking. (ABC Kimberley: Giulia Bertoglio)

Ms Waina is one of many residents of remote Aboriginal communities who make similar trips into town each year to access services.

Without suitable accommodation, many end up sleeping rough or staying with relatives in overcrowded houses.

Plans abandoned

The WA government had previously pledged $20 million to provide short-stay accommodation for residents of outlying communities travelling into Kununurra.

But the Cook government has since dumped the project, citing land limitations and a lack of suitable existing facilities.

Aboriginal short stay accommodation facilities, like this one in Derby, have been built across the state. (ABC News: Natalie Jones)

Housing and Works Minister John Carey said the funds had been reallocated to social housing in Kununurra and Wyndham, and would help deliver 32 homes over the next two years.

"I acknowledge there will be many people in the community disappointed by the decision to reallocate funding for the project," Mr Carey said.

"But our government is ensuring every dollar will be spent in the Kununurra and Wyndham communities."

Exposed to risks

Chermaine Dodd travelled to Kununurra from the Northern Territory for family reasons, but her stay has had its challenges.

"I'm struggling, I'm homeless, and I need somewhere to stay," she said.

Ms Dodd said an Aboriginal short-stay facility would help her and other visitors.

"I would feel safe as long as they provide us with a bed, with food, and as long as we do the right thing," she said.

Chermaine Dodd says overcrowding can create tension between family members. (ABC Kimberley: Giulia Bertoglio)

Ms Dodd said many visitors from remote communities ended up staying with relatives, even if they do not have room to accommodate them.

"It's overcrowded. It creates a bit of tension and family disputes, arguing," she said.

Edreena Unghango is visiting Kununurra from Kalumburu and staying with a relative.

But she said overcrowding was a real issue for some family and friends who had "somebody else sleeping on their bed, taking up their space" and resorted to going to the sober-up shelter.

Edreena Unghango says many people from remote communities have no choice but sleeping rough when visiting. (ABC Kimberley: Giulia Bertoglio)

While she has a bed in a safe home, Ms Unghango said she was worried for her younger relatives who slept rough when in town to access services or attend funerals.

"Sometimes you see families on the streets with babies," she said.

" I feel unsafe for my siblings, my baby sister, my baby brother. I like to ring up over time to make sure they are OK. "

'Sorely needed'

Shire of Wyndham-East Kimberley chief executive officer Vernon Lawrence said they would keep advocating for the facility to be built.

He said while there was a need for more social housing in Kununurra, an Aboriginal short stay was "sorely needed", with a lack of temporary accommodation exacerbating the town's social issues.

Vernon Lawrence said a short stay accommodation facility in Kununurra was "sorely needed". (ABC Kimberley: Giulia Bertoglio)

"Going through the COVID years and the increase in construction costs, there's no way a facility like that could be built for $20 million at this point," he said.

"It's an obvious, partial solution that can be implemented that hasn't been implemented."

Mr Lawrence said he hoped the government would ultimately find long-term funding to revive the project.

title: Sahar is worried sick, but hopes the day she can return to Iran is coming
text:
Sahar Agheli Goki believed that if she studied hard, she could have a good life in Iran.

But two years ago, her belief changed.

"When I graduated from university and started working, I realised as much as I try and work hard, I have nothing," Ms Goki said.

"So, I decided to leave Iran."

Ms Goki lives with her husband in Kalgoorlie, 600 kilometres from Perth, where she is studying a PhD in metallurgy.

Her new home, nestled at the end of a quiet, dusty street in the outback gold-mining city, is a stark contrast to what is unfolding in Iran.

Demonstrations broke out across Iran on December 28 over dire economic circumstances, but the protests quickly turned towards the country's clerical rulers and grew in number and size.

On January 8, the country descended into a communication blackout, and deadly demonstrations ensued.

For Ms Goki, the decision to leave has become bittersweet.

Ms Goki and her husband have been unable to contact family in Iran. (Supplied)

Her messages and calls to loved ones have gone unread.

"It's like they are not online. I also called them, and I can't reach them," Ms Goki said.

She does not know if her friends in Tehran are still alive and constantly worries about them.

Being on the other side of the world, Ms Goki said she could not help but feel ashamed that she was alive.

But she does not want to lose hope for her home country.

"I said to myself, 'That's enough — I'm not scared of this regime anymore,'" Ms Goki said.

"I want to do everything for this country. We have a long history, we had a big empire, so we don't deserve this."

Internet connectivity has been partially restored in Iran, but is operating around two per cent of ordinary levels, according to internet traffic monitoring services.

Ms Goki said on Sunday she had still not heard from her loved ones.

A time before the revolution

Ms Goki was born a decade after the 1979 revolution.

Growing up, she said her parents used to speak about how different life was in Iran before the start of the regime.

"My mother used to tell me about her school days under the Shah when children wore beautiful uniforms freely — that contrast made me sad and confused at a young age," Ms Goki said.

Ms Goki says she and her husband would consider returning to Iran if the situation improves. (Supplied)

The deepening economic crisis in Iran has become an enduring challenge for those living there.

"Every day, the price of the shop is twice [more expensive] — nobody can live like that."

But Ms Goki said it was deeper than just an economic issue.

"It's not like here — you can speak and have every opinion.

"They tell you what to wear, how to think, you can't even change religion because they don't let you."

Many Australians would find it difficult to imagine the situation, she said.

"When I came here and saw people wear whatever they want, I realised it's nothing," Ms Goki said.

"Just basic human rights."

Ms Goki says her husband, Farshid, has been a big source of support. (ABC Goldfields: Katrina Tap)

Despite being so far away, she is proud to be an Iranian.

"We have very beautiful architecture and so many different places with so many different characteristics," Ms Goki said.

"From north to south of Iran, you can experience spring and summer, and it's a beautiful country."

While there was always worry, Ms Goki held hope that now could be the time things changed.

Ms Goki is among Iranian nationals calling on countries to intervene.

"We can't do anything with bare hands," she said.

"We need people from outside to help."

While the lack of connectivity continues to limit access to developments in the country, there have been no new protests reported.

title: Australian artist's 'magic' letter box restoration project
text:
Mick Slocum's on a quest to resurrect a bit of Victorian history.

Nearly 200 bits, in fact.

The 76-year-old former Bushwackers band member is two years into his passion project, for which he travels the state refurbishing colonial-era postboxes — known as pillar boxes.

It's a job he believes is best done in period costume: often a tartan three-piece suit and a straw boater hat.

And it all started on an impulse.

"I was going through an anti-graffiti campaign," Mr Slocum said at a pillar box restoration in Albert Park.

"I bought some solvent and went and cleaned off the graffiti [from a pillar box].

"Then I stood back and … I thought goodness me, I think I'll just keep going."

Depending on their condition, Mick Slocum can spend weeks restoring historic pillar boxes. (ABC News: Scott Jewell)

Scrapers, some paint, and a passion for history

Mr Slocum's creative whim sprouted a personal campaign to restore every pillar box in the state.

After hearing about his first refurb, Australia Post offered Mick payment for every completed pillar. A supplier also provides paint.

Without any modern tools, he's scratched, scraped and painted pillars throughout Melbourne and across regional Victoria.

Each refurb takes between a couple of days and several weeks.

It's a task undertaken in the heat and cold, and along roads busy or quiet — and one that reliably draws curious onlookers, as well as offers to help.

"The gentleman whose [Albert Park] house I'm working out the front of came out and greeted me like a long-lost brother," Mr Slocum said.

"That's actually the best part — meeting the people."

Mick Slocum's restorations bring vibrant colour to Victorian streetscapes. (Supplied: Mick Slocum)

Secrets hidden beneath the surface

Pillar boxes were introduced in Australia in the 1850s.

Many were produced in several different styles at foundries in Melbourne.

Pillar boxes were key to communication in a time before the telephone and, along roads where cars and trams now zip by, horse-mounted postmen would have stopped multiple times a day to empty each one.

"The juxtaposition of what [an area] used to be like and what it is now is just extraordinary," Mr Slocum said.

"I'm kind of bringing that back in a way — that's the magic of it."

When the pillars were decommissioned, starting in the 1960s, they were sealed shut and were slathered with a bland, red coat of paint.

It's this dull coating Mick first shaves away before sanding and eventually returning the pillars back to their original colours — usually bright red, gold, and green.

The strips that come away with every scrape of Mick's knife can hint at a pillar's secret past: often revealing layers of colours which have been hidden for decades.

And some discoveries beneath the topcoat can be breathtaking.

Mick's fascinating finds in the past year include a delicate golden crown painted on a pillar box in Collingwood, which he believed was likely added ahead of Queen Elizabeth's visit in 1954.

In Jolimont, Mick uncovered a notice for collection times — which he estimated dated from the 1920s.

"But it could have even been from the 1800s," Mr Slocum said.

Scraping away the thick top coat on the pillars can reveal hidden secrets. (Supplied: Mick Slocum)

Boxes on the decline

There are about 180 pillar boxes in Victoria, but there were once thousands.

And it's not just the historic boxes that have disappeared from street corners.

With the rise of the internet and telephones, sending a letter has largely become a thing of the past and the number of modern post boxes has declined as well.

Australia Post has removed some receiving boxes in recent years.

In May 2025, Mick received a National Trust conservation award for his work in Ballarat — where he's refurbished 16 pillar boxes.

"He's provided a real highlight of the joy that heritage can spark in people's lives," said Sam Westbrook, executive manager of conservation and advocacy at National Trust.

70 down, 100 to go

Mick's nearly halfway to his target and has about 100 pillar box restorations to go.

But his unshakable passion for the colourful and creative means he already has his sights on his next project — once he's signed off on the final pillar box.

"In the CBD on every street corner there's an electricity box from the 1920s and 1930s," he said.

"So far I've restored two, and there are about 50 to go."

Mick Slocum scrapes, scratches and paints pillar boxes across Victoria (ABC News: Scott Jewell)

For now, he's focused on the main task — a project taken one pillar at a time.

"I always hope that one day I'll find a key that opens one of the boxes, and it'll be full of mail from the 1890s," Mr Slocum said with wide eyes and an eager smile.

"You just never know."

title: Live: Local wildcard nabs first win of Aus Open as thousands of fans stuck outside
text:
Local wildcard Talia Gibson has become the first winner on day one of the Australian Open, while top seeds Carlos Alcaraz and Aryna Sabalenka are the main attractions tonight.

Earlier, luckless Italian star Matteo Berrettini has withdrawn from his first-round Australian Open clash with Alex de Minaur on the eve of the tournament.

Follow all the latest from Melbourne Park in our live blog below.

Key Events We have our first seed knocked out 17 minutes ago Lines still long outside Melbourne Park 39 minutes ago Local wildcard Talia Gibson is the first winner of the 2026 Australian Open 1 hours ago Show all key events Australians in action on day one of the Aus Open J By Jon Healy Here are all the local hopes taking to the court on day one of the Australian Open (all times AEDT). Live: Corentin Moutet (32) vs Tristan Schoolkate on Kia Arena Coming up: Frances Tiafoe (29) vs Jason Kubler (Q) from 5pm on John Cain Arena

from 5pm on John Cain Arena Carlos Alcaraz (1) vs Adam Walton last on Rod Laver Arena Completed: Talia Gibson (WC) def Anna Blinkova 6-1, 6-3 Feder. Alcaraz. Sakkari. J By Jon Healy Greece's Maria Sakkari is through to the second round after beating Frenchwoman Leolia Jeanjean 6-4, 6-2 in an hour and 19 minutes on Margaret Court Arena. And the comprehensive victory gave us an early contender for shot of the tournament, with Sakkari ripping a forehand return winner around the net post at full stretch. "I could never imagine that I could actually hit that kind of return. "You see when Roger [Federer] hits it, Carlos [Alcaraz] and then myself. I'm pretty sure it's gonna [be] one of the best shots of the tournament." Zverev receives a warm reception as he enters RLA C By Chris De Silva Pretty kind reception for Alexander Zverev as he walks onto Rod Laver Arena behind Gabriel Diallo. The crowd is shuffling through the aisles at the moment, but there are a lot of empty seats in here as these two prepare to warm up. We have our first seed knocked out J By Jon Healy (Getty) Ukraine's Dayana Yastremska is the first singles seed to be knocked out of the main draw, the 26th seed going down in straight sets to Romania's Elena-Gabriela Ruse. Yastremska reached the semifinals here two years ago as a qualifier, but was outclassed by Ruse, who is ranked 76th in the world. Up next on RLA: Alexander Zverev opens his AO account C By Chris De Silva Last year's runner-up in the men's singles, Alexander Zverev, is up next at Rod Laver Arena. Zverev was well beaten by Jannik Sinner in last year's final and then received a less than ideal reception as he spoke after the match. It'll be interesting to see how the German is received this time around. Zverev is up against Canada's Gabriel Diallo first up. Jasmine Paolini coasts through to the second round on RLA J By Jon Healy (Getty) Aside from letting a couple of match points slip, barely a moment of trouble for Italian seventh seed Jasmine Paolini as she sweeps Belarusian Aliaksandra Sasnovich in 69 minutes. "Before the match I was a little bit nervous to be honest, but then I stepped on court and felt good from the first ball," she says on Rod Laver Arena. Paolini said she will relax and enjoy the rest of her Sunday now. (Supplied: Stan) Men's third seed Alex Zverev is next up on centre court, taking on Canada's Gabriel Diallo. Live: Another Australian on court J By Jon Healy Tristan Schoolkate has held serve to start his tournament on Kia Arena. The world number 97 is up against 34th-ranked Frenchman Corentin Moutet. Lines still long outside Melbourne Park J By Jon Healy (ABC Sport: Anthony Furci) It's hot and sunny outside the ground today and the sell-out crowd is slowly making its way through the gates. But it looks like thousands of people are stuck outside and battling to get inside, almost two hours after the scheduled start of play. (ABC Sport: Anthony Furci) Stay sun safe out there, folks. The moment Talia Gibson booked her place in the second round J By Jon Healy Local wildcard Talia Gibson is the first winner of the 2026 Australian Open J By Jon Healy (Getty) Australian wildcard Talia Gibson is through to the second round of her home slam for the second straight year with a decisive 6-1, 6-3 victory over Russian Anna Blinkova in just 76 minutes. Gibson was fearless and finished the match by ripping a 43rd winner across the court (Blinkova only had five). It's a phenomenal victory for Gibson, who is ranked 119th, 57 spots below Blinkova. Gibson gets emotional as she thanks the fans on Kia Arena for getting behind her. "I couldn't believe the number of people that were in here today. It just means a lot. Thank you so much." Live: Upset watch on John Cain Arena J By Jon Healy What is happening with Flavio Cobolli on JCA? Trainers have been with him at every change of ends - Stanchez (Getty) Italian 20th seed Flavio Cobolli has just dropped the first-set tiebreak 7-1 to qualifier Arthur Fery and immediately left the court for a toilet break. The Italian has been struggling a little physically and certainly looked out of sorts. It's also been a weird match with a video review for a net touch and a let played after an underarm serve because the ballkid was moving behind Cobolli. Live: Talia Gibson tightening up a little J By Jon Healy Australian wildcard Talia Gibson could be the first winner at this Australian Open, but the 21-year-old is showing some nerves as her match against Anna Blinkova rolls on. The match is just over an hour old and she leads Blinkova 6-1, 4-3 thanks largely to a 33-5 advantage in winners, but she's just been broken for the first time and the unforced errors are mounting now too (20-12). Gibson missed a chance to go up 5-1 on Blinkova's serve and has started missing a few more serves and she's getting a little rushed as Blinkova finds her rhythm. Huge lines at Melbourne Park J By Jon Healy It would be great if we could actually watch the games, we’ve been stood in line in the burning sun for 40 minutes now 😔 - Claire Shepley Oh Claire, I hope you've got your sunscreen on. (ABC Sport: Anthony Furci) The lines are massive outside the precinct with ground passes sold out for day one. Hopefully you can get in soon and enjoy the tennis. Live: Talia Gibson takes the opening set J By Jon Healy It's taken just 31 minutes for West Australian wildcard Talia Gibson to become the first player to win a set in the main draw at the Australian Open. She's just demolished world number 62 Anna Blinkova with gutsy groundstrokes and nerveless play, ripping 13 winners to 2 and winning 88 per cent of her first-serve points (albeit only landing it 40 per cent of the time). When is Alex Eala playing? J By Jon Healy You able to also report on Alex Eala? - Rey Hi Rey, We will report on Alex Eala, but the 20-year-old from the Philippines isn't playing until Monday. She starts her campaign against American Alycia Parks in the second match on court six tomorrow. Live: Clutch from Talia Gibson J By Jon Healy (Getty) If Talia Gibson is nervous about playing at her home grand slam for just the third time, she isn't showing it. The 21-year-old is crushing her groundstrokes and nailing serves on big points, saving two break points in her second service game, then breaking again to extend her first-set lead over Anna Blinkova to 4-1. The 27-year-old Russian is not only ranked 62nd as opposed to Gibson's 119, she has also played almost twice as many singles matches on tour. Action about to kick off on the main courts J By Jon Healy The first players of the main draw are set to start on the big arenas in just a minute. First up on Rod Laver Arena we have seventh seed Jasmine Paolini and Belarusian qualifier Aliaksandra Sasnovich: While on Margaret Court Arena it's Greek former world number three Maria Sakkari against Leolia Jeanjean, the 101st-ranked Frenchwoman who is coming off successive losses against Belinda Bencic and Paolini at the United Cup: Live: Talia Gibson opens her Open with a break J By Jon Healy Australian wildcard Talia Gibson has broken in the first game of the tournament, punishing some poor serving from Anna Blinkova. Gibson is ranked 119th in the world, 57 spots lower than Blinkova, but is making the early running on Kia Arena Day groundpasses already sold out for day one C By Chris De Silva (Getty) Talk about anticipation for this Australian Open being at fever pitch already! Play has barely begun at Melbourne Park and groundpasses for the day session have already been exhausted. Huge rankings leap for Aussie women J By Jon Healy Kim Birrell (left) and Taylah Preston (right). (Getty/AP) On the eve of the Australian Open, two Australian women have had enormous rankings boosts thanks to their semifinal runs. Kim Birrell has leapt 31 places to 76th in the world rankings after her run in Adelaide, while Taylah Preston jumped 43 places to 161 thanks to her Hobart tournament that ended at the second least hurdle. Those are the biggest jumps by any players in the top 289 on the WTA rankings. Show more posts

title: How trailblazing strikers jumped out of windows to oppose government control
text:
A whistle rings out. Evening is falling, and it's time for the people of the Torres Strait to abide by their night-time curfew.

It was almost a century ago that the call of the "bu", or trumpet shell, controlled the lives of those across the islands of the Torres Strait.

Once used by chiefs to call men to battle, the bu, as it was known, became a tool of oppression.

The pearling industry dominated the Torres Strait economy in 1936. (State Library of Queensland)

That was, until January 1936, when Torres Strait Islanders decided they had had enough of the discrimination they suffered working on pearling boats.

They went on strike.

This week, Governor-General Sam Mostyn attended a ceremony on Thursday Island commemorating the 90th anniversary of the strike.

Ms Mostyn said the story "has not really manifested itself in a way that others have historically for Australia".

Ned David (right) and Torres Strait mayors led a parade on Thursday Island commemorating the maritime strike. (Supplied: Duncan Bain)

"It shouldn't have taken 90 years to really reflect on this and to learn from what happened in the 1930s and think about how that did shape other things across the country," she said.

"We know a lot about the Wave Hill Walk-Off and the Gurindji people, we know about the Mabo decision and native title, but the thing that has struck me is this story has so much extraordinary background to it.

"I think what we saw [on Thursday Island this week] was the pride in what happened in the 1930s.

"There are many family members, descendants of those strikers, who knew how tough it was to live at that time."

Oppression and control

Back then, the Queensland Government Protector controlled the lives of Torres Strait Islanders, dictating where they could go, how they worked and how they got paid.

For most, that work was in the pearling industry.

"A chap by the name of J.D. McLean took up post here in the late [19]20s and started putting some of these new, really restrictive suppressive laws in place," said Ned David, chairman of the Torres Strait Islander land and sea council known as Gur A Baradharaw Kod.

Ned David reflects on the legacy of the maritime strike. (ABC Far North: Brendan Mounter)

The Torres Strait supplied much of the global demand for pearls, and the industry employed most of the archipelago's workforce.

While some Islanders worked on so-called "master's boats", owned by European or Japanese pearlers, many were employed on "company" boats controlled by the Queensland Government Protector.

The company's boat system was restrictive and paid lower wages.

In many cases, they did not receive cash but credit that could be spent only at designated government stores.

McLean wanted to boost production on the company boats, but his oppressive approach sparked a revolt with ramifications far beyond pearling.

Michael O'Shane is a long-serving member of the Maritime Union of Australia. (ABC Far North: Brendan Mounter)

Michael O'Shane, whose grandmother used to dive for trochus shells around Masig Island, has heard family stories about the "invasive, exploitative" regime of the protector days.

"They were only paid with flour, sugar and tobacco and stuff like that," he said.

"[Torres Strait Islanders] built the luggers, they owned and operated the luggers, but it was at the protector's discretion on the administration of it, the working of it, the crewing of it, how they were paid."

Torres Strait Islanders' money and movement were strictly controlled by a Queensland Government Protector. (State Library of Queensland)

More than just money

By January 1936, the Torres Strait Islanders had enough.

When McLean went around trying to sign up workers for the company boats, Torres Strait Islanders refused, jumping out of meeting hall windows in protest.

The strike made headlines in the Cairns and Brisbane dailies, and after nine months, McLean was removed from his post and replaced by another protector.

The nightly curfew was scrapped, and Torres Strait Islander pearlers were given more pay, control of their own boats and more freedom to travel between islands without the need for permission.

"You can only imagine back then, with limited means of communication — there was nothing like a telephone or anything — how people were able to organise themselves to basically synchronise the strike to take place at almost the same time across the entire region," Mr David said.

"It's very interesting to know that our people came together, sat down and said 'we're not going to take this anymore,'" Mr O'Shane said.

Pearl racks off Friday Island are one of the remaining signs of a once-massive industry that boomed across the Torres Strait. (Nikolai Beilharz: ABC Rural)

"We stand on those shoulders today."

Mr O'Shane, a maritime worker and unionist, said the actions of his ancestors resonated with the broader Australian value of a fair go.

"It exposed the situation to the world, what was happening to the First Nations people of his country," he said.

title: Tourists triple the population of this coastal town, and some never leave
text:
It's the picturesque kind of place travellers visit once and decide to stay.

Angus Darling was tripping around the country in a caravan with his wife and children when he made a stop at Agnes Water, a coastal town in central Queensland.

"It does suck people in," Mr Darling said.

"But it's not until you live here and you start connecting with people and it really does draw you into that Agnes bubble," he said.

Angus Darling decided to settle in Agnes Water with his family after travelling around Australia. (ABC News: Nandini Dhir)

Part of the town's "bubble" are ex-professional surfer Zane Harrison, who runs a local surf school, and board maker Bruce Palmer.

Agnes Water is known to have some of the most northerly point breaks on Australia's east coast, with "secret" secluded beaches part of its allure.

Despite having smaller or inconsistent waves at times, the coastal town is loved by surfers. (Supplied: Surfs Up Eastern Suburbs)

Mr Darling has lived in the town since 2021, working remotely for his employer in Sydney.

It didn't take him long to be elected president of the Tide n Turn Boardriders Club—a position he has held for two years now.

It is one of the oldest boardriding clubs in the country, having turned 60 last year.

"[The club] really started as a group of mates coming down to hang out and camp, and they used to get waves … but it was more just about that connection," Mr Darling said.

The surf community in Agnes Water has grown, particularly with the influx of young families in the area. (ABC News: Nandini Dhir)

An avid surfer himself, Mr Darling said the club had seen a surge in memberships from young families who moved to the region around the pandemic.

Paul White has lived in the town for the past 25 years and has helped foster the community's love of surfing.

Paul White says the surf in Agnes Water is not "consistent". (ABC News: Nandini Dhir)

"There's surf right along the coastline to where the Great Barrier Reef chops [the swell] off … so there's all these little magical beaches," he said.

Mr White is the director of the local longboard classic surf competition, an event he said has grown as more families chose Agnes and the nearby town of Seventeen Seventy as their homes.

The Agnes Water Longboard Classic competition kicks off in March. (Supplied: Surfs Up Eastern Suburbs)

He said while the waves were not always consistent, surfers here have a better chance out on the water.

"You go out surfing for the day, and you get 30 to 40 waves in your session here at Agnes Water, and you feel really great because you've done what surfing's about," Mr White said.

"[But] down south, they're populated, it's hard to get waves."

A competitor at the Agnes Water Longboard Classic. (Supplied: Surfs Up Eastern Suburbs)

Small town, small surf

With a population of less than 3,000 people, Agnes Water has become a laid-back tourism destination.

Amber Rodgers says the gentle waves at Agnes Water and 1770 make the beaches appealing to beginner surfers. (ABC News: Jasmine Hines)

President of Discovery Coast Tourism and Commerce, Amber Rodgers, said the town's population roughly tripled during peak holiday periods.

"Essentially for us, domestic visitors are really our number one bread and butter, all year-round, and from all parts of the country," Ms Rodgers said.

"We see caravaners from Adelaide and Victoria, we see a lot of local people from just within our 400 [kilometre] radius close to here, and they often love to visit more than once a year."

The Agnes Water main beach is loved by locals, tourists and pooches. (ABC News: Jasmine Hines)

Ms Rodgers said the region had an average of 300 days of sunshine, and the main beach offered beginners excellent conditions for learning to surf.

According to the most recent census data, from 2016 to 2021, the Agnes Water and Seventeen Seventy area grew in population by about 25 per cent.

Secret spots and camaraderie

Despite its popularity, locals said visitors don't generally come for the waves, which can be irregular or small.

Amber Walker got involved with the local surf club before becoming an instructor herself. (ABC News: Nandini Dhir)

Surf instructor Amber Walker moved with her family to Agnes Water and has been a member of the boardriders club for about a decade.

"The waves definitely don't attract people because they're not consistent, but it's more so the small town and the community that you only get in small country towns," she said.

"It's the friendship, it's the camaraderie, all those things."

The town is known for its sense of community and love of the outdoors. (ABC News: Jasmine Hines)

She joined the club for social reasons and later became an instructor at a local surf school.

Ayla Klicker, 17, moved to the town with her family a decade ago.

She had surf lessons with Ms Walker for about a year.

Ayla Klicker says the secret surf spots at Agnes Water will "have to stay secret". (ABC News: Nandini Dhir)

Ms Klicker said she used to be apprehensive about getting into the water but felt welcomed by other surfers.

"I used to be super scared going out because there weren't that many girls that surf … but recently there's been a lot more girls getting into it," Ms Klicker said.

She said she had built her confidence and had discovered several secret spots.

"We've got some secret spots, and you'll never see anyone at them, so they'll have to stay secret … but it's super fun if you look for them," Ms Klicker said.

title: Work with kids, instead of destroying their bike jumps, authorities told
text:
In a patch of private bushland outside Launceston, 16-year-old Zeke Woolcock meticulously crafts piles of dirt into jumps and berms.

Using only handheld tools, he and his mates have moved tonnes of dirt in recent months, spending their free time and the boundless energy teenagers possess.

But this is the second time Zeke has transformed a landscape into a biking playground, and he admits that, not knowing any better, the first time around, he did the wrong thing.

His first jumps were built on public land, where any development needs assessment for safety, conservation and heritage reasons, and one day he woke up to a text from a mate saying they had been destroyed.

Fellow bike enthusiast Robert Potter follows Zeke over the bike jumps he built. (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

Authorities destroying bike jumps built illegally by kids is not a new thing, but research indicates that those authorities should instead seek to work with young people on building trails.

And that is what a Launceston-based professional trail builder wants to do.

Teenager built 'pride and joy' in the wrong place

Like many kids, Zeke fell in love with riding bikes at a young age and quickly progressed to higher and higher skill levels, now capable of technical tricks over large jumps at speed.

He started building jumps a few years ago near his home in a Launceston suburb and then progressed to bushland near the city's stadium.

He said he and his mates put in months of work, often at night after TAFE and school, over winter, building the jumps.

"We found a really good convenient location with good dirt that was right next to the Silverdome," he said.

"I'd probably done four of five months of work. Quite a few long nights in the dark … just building and building and building."

Zeke and his mates built their first lot of jumps on public land near Prospect in northern Tasmania. (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

But that's where he ran into trouble, because that "good dirt" was in the Kate Reed Nature Recreation Area, which is public land managed by the Parks and Wildlife Service.

The PWS subsequently destroyed the jumps.

"I saw my pride and joy being taken down," Zeke said.

Zeke estimates he and his mates spent five months building the jumps that were ultimately destroyed. (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

There are mountain bike tracks in the reserve, but they have been officially sanctioned by the PWS and conform to safety and conservation requirements.

Neighbour dobs children into council over bike jumps Brisbane City Council has destroyed "incredibly dangerous" bike jumps at Bulimba's Johnston Park which it said could get it sued if a child injured themselves.

Zeke said he should have been "more responsible".

"The first few days I was quite upset … but I did realise in the end it was the wrong thing to be doing."

In a statement, the PWS said it removed "illegal jumps" from the area in July 2025.

"These jumps were unsafe for general public use and not built to standard," a spokesperson said.

"Without the required assessments, developments can impact threatened species, communities and Aboriginal heritage.

" Inappropriate construction may also cause erosion and safety issues. "

Tasmania's parks service says the jumps were "unsafe for general public use and not built to standard". (Supplied: Tasmania Parks and Wildlife Service)

Trail builder built career out of teenage hobby

Robert Potter builds mountain bike trails for a living, and knows all too well how much young people like to build jumps in the bush.

"This happens all around the world," he said.

" Thirty years ago I was doing exactly the same thing and the jumps would be flattened, and we would build them again. "

Mr Potter has been building bike jumps since he was a kid and now does it for a living. (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

He believes the best way to overcome the problem is to involve young people in building and maintaining officially sanctioned trails.

"We really do need to find a way to harness the enthusiasm and ability of the riders who want to contribute to maintaining these public assets," he said.

"Often, the best we can do is to replicate what the kids are building for themselves.

" But that doesn't satisfy the need they have to actually do the building and all the good things that come from that. "

Mr Potter says officials will often replicate the bike jumps built by young people. (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

Teamwork, leadership dug out of the dirt

Tasmanian course praised after hosting national championships Australia's best mountain bike riders battle for the national championship in north-east Tasmania.

University of Melbourne researcher David Camilleri has been looking at those "good things".

Dr Camilleri said when young people worked together to build jumps in the bush, it could foster leadership, teach problem solving and create a sense of community.

"It's just young people wanting to create a space for themselves," he said.

" And they do it using shovels and digging these jumps and going there and riding together and building these same social connections. "

Dr Camilleri collaborates with local councils and community groups to promote BMX as a tool for mental health and wellbeing. (Supplied: David Camilleri)

Zeke said those were exactly the types of things he felt he learned while building his jumps with his mates.

"I've found it has really helped me become a leader."

Mr Potter said it was that type of environment that led him to the career he has today.

"We developed a community around the jumps that we had," he said.

But there may be positive outcomes that can be disrupted when jumps are destroyed.

"The demolition of jumps can also erode trust in governments and institutions," Dr Camilleri said.

The first lot of bike jumps Zeke built were destroyed. (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

The researcher suggests, as Mr Potter has done, that authorities should engage and consult with young people about approved tracks, and explain why unsanctioned tracks may be unsafe.

The Parks and Wildlife Service said it sought to consult with the builder of the illegal jumps removed last year, but no communication was received.

"PWS and the Launceston Mountain Bike Club continue to work together to ensure appropriate approval processes are adhered to and that tracks in the area are at an appropriate safe standard for public users," it said.

" Young people and all members of the public are encouraged to liaise and work with PWS and the Launceston Mountain Bike Club on any proposed future developments. "

State's mountain bike tracks not always accessible

Zeke is still working on his jumps on private land near Kate Reed, and has had some positive feedback on his efforts.

But even without that, he said he would still want to find ways to continue building jumps with his mates.

" Even if I had nowhere to build, I would still find a way to do it. "

Zeke says building bike jumps with his mates helped him "become a leader". (ABC News: Morgan Timms)

He said that even though Tasmania has a lot of well-built, approved bike riding trails in places like Derby and Maydena, he's not often able to travel.

"People can go to other parts of the state and get some amazing mountain bike trails, but I didn't really have that option," he said.

" So instead of going over to bike parks, I decided I'd bring the bike parks to me. "

title: None in family history, yet 'cancer still found us in the worst way'
text:
At the end of every day the Barrett family puts a colourful sticker on the lounge room wall.

It is a symbol they have survived another day without their precious daughter and sister Abbey who died of brain cancer 18 months ago.

She was 11.

Justine says that since losing Abbey the family "talk a lot about her" as a means of coping. (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

Mother Justine, father Rick and sisters Willow and Tasmin try to honour Abbey in little ways every day.

Her teddy is at the dinner table where she used to sit and a vegetable patch has been replaced with a flower garden.

"None of it feels like enough but we're very open, we talk a lot about her," Justine said.

" The grief is brutal. "

Abbey Barrett in hospital during treatment. (Supplied: Barrett family)

If you or anyone you know needs grief support: Griefline: Phone support for all Australians Monday to Friday and 24/7 online forums. Call 1300 845 745 from 8:00am to 8:00pm AEDT

from 8:00am to 8:00pm AEDT Lifeline: 24-hour support for all Australians on 13 11 14

Abbey was the youngest of the girls, all close in age, and a "cool human" according to Justine.

"She was joy on two legs. She was like a puppy, she just brought that energy and joy," she said.

When Abbey was 10, her parents noticed she was tired and had developed hand tremors.

She had a blood test and everything was normal.

But when she started having trouble with her vision, an MRI revealed she had a brain tumour the size of a fist wrapped around her brain stem.

The family felt a shock "almost like an earthquake".

Justine says they decided "when you die you go to a park that's full of loaded fruit trees and puppies". (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

"We have no family history of cancer. Yet cancer still found us in the worst way," Justine said.

"We went from having Lego and books on the kitchen table to medications and cancer brochures. It was incredibly surreal," she said.

Abbey had two brain surgeries, chemotherapy and radiation.

While the Barretts were supported by medical professionals, navigating her care was difficult, with them needing to make calls on when to take her to hospital or when to manage her symptoms at home.

Abbey's mother Justine said her daughter knew she was dying. (Supplied: Barrett family)

" These decisions were one of the hardest parts because the consequences of making the wrong decision were literally life and death. "

'She died at home, in our bed, in my arms'

Justine said Abbey knew she was dying.

"I had to have conversations with her about what that meant," Justine recalled.

" We decided that when you die you go to a park that's full of loaded fruit trees and puppies. "

Justine says her other daughters struggle with the weight of the grief of losing Abbey. (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

Abbey died a year after her diagnosis.

"She died at home, in our bed, in my arms. We tried to make her death as gentle and easy as possible," Justine said.

But Abbey's death was far from easy.

"Why don't we have voluntary assisted dying for children? The last ten hours of Abbey's life were agony to witness," Justine said.

At the same time, Abbey's parents needed to consider how their other two girls were coping.

They wanted to normalise the death and grieving as much as they could.

"After she died we drew pictures and wrote messages on her stomach and arms as a way of sending her body off with love," Justine recalled.

She said her daughters struggle with the weight of the grief of losing their sister Abbey.

"They've had some pretty big challenges since," Justine said.

"I am really proud of them, it's been a really big journey."

Abbey's sisters and the many photos of Abbey in their home. (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

Older sister Willow said she felt helpless watching Abbey suffer through brain cancer.

"I don't think I can put into words how hard it was," she said.

"My mental health journey has been very bumpy since so I am having to do part-time at school."

Justine has chosen to share her family's story, hoping it will send message to the Australian government.

"Put some funding towards brain cancer, because we're failing our children," she said.

" Our job as adults, at the very least, is to raise our children to become adults themselves and we're failing that. "

Abbey Barrett died a year after her diagnosis. (Supplied: Barrett family)

The 'horrible' statistics

Brain cancer, often described as "rare", accounts for about 2 per cent of all cancers.

To put that figure into perspective, more Australians die of brain cancer than the number of people killed in road accidents every year.

Remembering Charlie and others gone far too soon because of brain cancer The memory of Charlie, symbolised by shoes and his story, will be just one of many taken to Canberra to "raise awareness of the horrific effects and unimproved life expectancy from brain tumours".

In 2023, Australia saw 1,579 people die from brain cancer, compared with 1,254 road crash deaths that same year.

It's the disease that kills more Australian children under 14 than any other.

Brain cancer's five-year survival rates have only improved marginally in the last three decades, from 19 per cent (1990-1994) to 23 per cent (2015-2019).

"That flat, virtually flat curve and low survivability is a horrible statistic," said Craig Cardinal from Brain Tumour Alliance Australia.

" It's hard not to be heartbroken by that. "

Brain cancer victims are remembered at Parliament House, Canberra, as part of 2025 Head to the Hill event. (ABC News: Andy Cunningham)

In recent years the shoes of Australians who have lost their lives to the disease have been placed on the lawns outside Parliament House in Canberra.

It's a call for action and funding.

Renowned doctor's cancer battle 'getting closer' to the end Former Australian of the Year Richard Scolyer made the comments next to the prime minister after a position at Chris O'Brien Lifehouse was named after him.

Dr Rosemary Harrup is a medical oncologist and researcher at the Menzies Institute for Medical Research in Tasmania.

She said while there is a range of different brain cancers, the most aggressive is glioblastoma.

"About a quarter of these people are alive at two years [after diagnosis]. These are devastating figures," Dr Harrup said.

New techniques to cross the blood-brain barrier offering hope

While brain cancer is complex and difficult to treat, surgical techniques to remove tumours have improved in recent years.

"Unfortunately there's always going to be residual cells from which the cancer will regrow," Dr Harrup said.

Professor Rosemary Harrup is one of those working to solve the blood-brain barrier puzzle. (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

Treatments span radiotherapy, chemotherapy and immunotherapy — but there are challenges.

The brain is protected by an intricate network of blood vessels, which work to protect it from foreign materials.

"That's called the blood-brain barrier, and so most treatments need to be able to cross that to be effective," Dr Harrup said.

She said an international study using ultrasound to open the blood-brain barrier for short periods, combined with chemotherapy, is proving promising.

"It's almost like science fiction and can allow the drug just in that short window of opportunity to cross into the brain."

Researchers at the Menzies Institute are using flies to help develop brain cancer treatments for humans. (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

Working out which part of the puzzle is broken

Associate Professor Phillippa Taberlay and her team at the Menzies Institute are working on finding solutions at the DNA level, looking at a type of childhood cancer called medulloblastoma.

"It's a type of cancer which has a very high rate of epigenetic dysregulation, which means the way genes are expressed have been altered," Dr Taberlay said.

" We are looking at how DNA inside of the cell is folded or modified with little chemical tags. "

Dr Phillippa Taberlay says discoveries about brain cancer are applied to other cancers. (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

She said understanding which chemical tags aren't behaving as they should will help determine where the fault in the body is.

"If we can discover which proteins or parts of the puzzle are broken we will be able to use really sophisticated genetic tools or new pharmacology to treat brain cancers," she said.

Dr Taberlay believes any discoveries about brain cancer could be applied to other cancers.

Abbey is remembered by her family as being "like a puppy … she just brought that energy and joy". (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

Brain cancer missing out on funding

Clinical trials of new treatments can offer hope to cancer patients, but Dr Harrup said funding for them is limited.

"It is unfortunate that if you live in a major capital city and you have brain cancer you are much more likely to be able to enrol in a clinical trial than if you live in country Victoria or Tasmania," she said.

Brain cancer's survival rates have changed little over the past 30 years and is the cancer that kills the most children in Australia. (ABC News: Andy Cunningham)

Brain Tumour Alliance Australia has been mapping the burden and economic cost of brain cancer in Australia, which in 2025 was $850 million.

If trends continue the mapping estimates the cost at $3.2 billion by 2050.

It's hoped the mapping will unite the brain cancer community and fundraising efforts, and make research and funding a government priority.

Justine leafs through a scrapbook for Abbey, her tattoo tribute visible on her wrist. (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

The alliance is asking the federal government for $200 million over 10 years for brain cancer research and trials, and up to $10 million to improve clinical care for patients, including funding for specialised nurses.

"The burdens and impacts are disproportionately high, the complexity of the disease is disproportionately high, but our funding and policy approach to address that complexity is mismatched," Mr Cardinal said.

Craig Cardinal is one of those heading the campaign to lobby for more money to fight the disease. (ABC News: Mark Moore)

The Alliance said direct research funding for brain cancer has consistently lagged behind other cancers.

It states that from 2003 to 2020 brain cancer received $111.6 million in total project funding — well below breast cancer ($431.6 million) and leukaemia ($234.7 million).

In 2017 the Australian Brain Cancer Mission invested $126 million over 10 years for brain cancer research, $50 million came from government, while $76 million was from philanthropic organisations.

"I'm certainly committed to doing more … as that mission comes to an end. We've already started discussions with the Brain Cancer Alliance about what that looks like," said federal Health Minister Mark Butler.

Mark Butler says the government is "working as hard as we can" to get cancer drugs on the PBS "as quickly as possible". (ABC News: Rebecca Trigger)

"In the meantime whenever there are new treatments, particularly for children with brain cancer, we're working as hard as we can to get those medicines available to families on the PBS as quickly as possible.

" This is a stubborn area of cancer where I think every country, including ours, wants to see improvement. "

Dr Harrup said "talking about a cure is important because that's what we strive for and that's what our mission is."

"For those patients we can't cure right here and now, improving quality of life and quantity of life are both very, very meaningful goals," she said.

title: Breakdancing stars in Brisbane to bid for Olympics inclusion
text:
Inside the prestigious Brisbane City Hall in the countdown to the 2032 Olympic Games, thumping music shakes the walls where almost 200 breakdancers from across 33 countries have gathered to compete.

This weekend's World Dancesport Federation competition is part of the bid to secure the sport's presence at the 2032 Brisbane Olympic and Paralympic Games.

Benmx has been breaking since his family moved to Queensland in 2015. (Supplied)

Amongst the talented competitors is a group of Australian athletes determined to define their own Olympic image, emerging from the shadow cast by Raygun at the last Games.

"It was just that small snippet: there's so much more to breaking," said Benji Cogdell-Baird, acclaimed on an international stage as Benmx.

The 18-year-old has been breaking since his family moved to Queensland from South Australia when he was seven.

Benmx says breaking gave him an outlet when his brother was ill. (Supplied)

"When we moved up here, my brother had a cardiac arrest. At the time, it was very stressful for my parents having to manage all of that," he said.

"They put me in the sport to take my mind off all the things that were happening.

"They put me in the sport to take my mind off all the things that were happening," Benmx says. (Supplied)

"It was explosive and powerful. I just ended up falling in love with it straight away."

The Gold Coast teenager said he wanted more Australians to feel that passion for a sport that was not "too exposed" on home soil.

Benmx was born in South Australia but now calls the Gold Coast home. (ABC News: Lucy Loram)

"I'd like to show the world that it's such an entertaining sport and it's like none other. When was the last time you saw [someone] spinning on their head?"

The teenager wants more Australians to feel the passion. (Supplied)

'Individual personalities and flavours'

The words 'Australian breakdancer' became tied to one notable performer in 2024, when Raygun hopped around the Olympic stage in green and gold. She failed to score any points in her three bouts in Paris.

The routines made international headlines, but general secretary of DanceSport Australia Luke Brown said it was time for other Olympic and non-Olympic breakers to take over the spotlight.

"Paris 2024 was an amazing success for breaking. Raygun represented Australia, and she went forward and bought what she thought was her best performance," he said.

Luke Brown says breaking deserves its place in the Olympics. (ABC News: Lucy Loram)

" But we're moving forward in a way that showcases all of our athletes and their own individual personalities and flavours. "

Professional breaker J-Attack, otherwise known as Jeff Dunne, had a taste of the Olympic limelight at the Paris Games.

"Just being able to represent Australia at one of the highest sporting areas is such an honour and such a privilege," he said.

Loading Instagram content

With five billion people watching the Paris Olympics two years ago, Mr Dunne said he was hopeful that breaking could reach similar audiences from Brisbane in six years' time.

"I'd like Australia to understand the difference between watching breaking and seeing it live," he said.

"It also allows competitors to travel across the world to meet new people that share the same experience as you, who have put in all that hard work and discipline."

17-year-old Guo Pu from China, who is ranked number one in world youth under the stage name B-Girl Royal, said the lively art form was active across the world, including in Australia.

"I don't think there is a big difference in communities because we are altogether dancing for our love of this sport and art form," she said.

"We hope to invite more people to experience and appreciate breaking."

Mr Brown said fresh talent were accepting that invitation, within the scope of World DanceSport Federation competitions.

"We're seeing an increase of participation across the country, we're not seeing a decrease," he said.

"We're seeing an increase of registrations worldwide and in Australia as well."

Jeff 'J-Attack' Dunne represented Australia in the 2024 Olympics for breaking. (Reuters: Angelika Warmuth)

Olympic prospects

Breaking was one of many sports vying to be selected by the international Olympic and Paralympic committees for the 2032 program.

Why Raygun hit a nerve There's an elite club of Olympic losers who we love to celebrate. A year on from Raygun's infamous performance, Australian Story investigates why she isn't one of them.

"We are focused on designing a sport programme that reflects the values of the Olympic and Paralympic Movements, is operationally viable, and supports Brisbane 2032's commercial, sustainable and engagement and experience objectives," said a Brisbane 2032 spokesperson.

With the sport not featuring in the 2028 Los Angeles Games, its fate in Brisbane will be decided by the committees later this year.

President of the World DanceSport Federation, Shawn Tay, said the weekend's competition in Brisbane was a positive sign that Australia had an appetite for global breakdancing performances.

"This is perhaps the most important event before the Olympic Games Committee makes its decision to include new sports in Brisbane 2032," Mr Tay said.

"Many of our top athletes are here, including many young world champions, to showcase what they do best in breaking."

title: Crashes thwart Australian team on day one of women's Tour Down Under
text:
Crash carnage has put the Australian Liv Jayco AlUla team on the back foot at the women's Tour Down Under.

While they are at least one rider down heading into Sunday's second stage, New Zealander Ally Wollaston and her FDJ United-Suez teammates will try to retain the race leader's ochre jersey.

Italian Alessia Vigilia, who left FDJ at the end of last season, is also off to a great start at Uno-X Mobility thanks to her 100km solo break, which was caught only within 300m of the finish on Saturday at Willunga.

Liv AlUla Jayco came into the Santos Tour on the back of an outstanding campaign at the Australian road cycling championships in Perth.

Ruby Roseman-Gannon won the criterium and first-year WorldTour rider Mackenzie Coupland capitalised on great team riding to clinch the women's elite road race.

It was in stark contrast to the Jayco AlUla men, who botched the finish to their elite road race.

But Liv AlUla Jayco lost some crucial horsepower during the week when Amber Pate crashed in training. She did not start stage one because of her injuries.

Then inside the last couple of kilometres on Saturday, a crash took out Roseman-Gannon and several teammates.

Georgia Baker was left with a bloodied knee and has been withdrawn from the second stage.

"All the riders have been through their fair share of crashes in their careers, so when you walk away like this … it can be a lot worse," team manager Jess Allen said.

"It's not what you want, but we also have two days ahead and two new opportunities to turn things around."

The Tour will continue on Sunday with the 130.7km stage from suburban Norwood to Paracombe in the Adelaide Hills.

Wollaston probably will not retain the overall lead given the climbing involved on Sunday, but she is determined to make opponents work for it.

"I will try and do it justice — it would be rude not to," she said.

"You have to respect a jersey like this in the WorldTour. We'll do everything tomorrow as a team to keep this jersey in the team."

Despite being overtaken so close to the finish, Vigilia was also upbeat about her form and settling into her new team.

"It's really nice to feel that we work well. It's hard to arrive here and adapt to the jet lag and heat," she said.

"So this is a good sign that we are prepared and we will show it again."

AAP

title: Do you remember these seven songs from the Hottest 100 of 2005?
text:
Every year, Double J counts down the Hottest 100 from 20 years ago.

It's a chance for some of us to reminisce about simpler times, and for younger music fans to discover songs that might have slipped through the cracks.

It's not that these tracks aren't great — far from it — but with thousands of tunes released every year, even the best can fade from memory.

These 10 really struck us when looking at the full list from the 2005 Hottest 100, and we want to share them with you.

We're not saying your memory's shot. We just want to bring these gems back into your life.

So, settle in and get ready to revisit some of the highlights from a truly great year in music.

The Bloodhound Gang — Foxtrot Uniform Charlie Kilo (#24)

The title, Foxtrot Uniform Charlie Kilo, sues the NATO phonetic alphabet to communicate the song's subject matter. (Supplied: Geffen Records)

YouTube | Spotify | Apple Music

Six years after cracking the Hottest 100 top 10 with The Bad Touch — whose words were deeply etched into the minds of every 2000s schoolyard kid — The Bloodhound Gang returned to the countdown with Foxtrot Uniform Charlie Kilo in 2005.

Though it capitalises on the same sexual innuendo schtick, can you dig up a single line from the memory bank? I sure as heck can't.

The track's generic alt-rock and music video — featuring bikini models with power tools and Bam Margera driving a banana car through a tunnel — have not aged well. But the song's various slang for intercourse ("Marinate the nether rod in the squish mitten… Batter dip the cranny ax in the gut locker") can still elicit a chuckle or two.

Al Newstead

Architecture in Helsinki — It'5! (#56)

It'5! was a highlight of Architecture In Helsinki's dazzling second album (Inertia Music)

YouTube | Spotify | Apple Music

They ended up reaching far greater heights, including two spots in the Hottest 100 top 20 in following years, but It'5! gave Architecture In Helsinki their first ever spot in the Hottest 100.

The song was a highlight of In Case We Die, the second album from the Melbourne pop experimentalists, and sounded like nothing else in the countdown.

This nonlinear blast of chamber pop jumps around a lot, packing chorus vocals, brass sections, nursery rhyme chanting, and lots of handclaps into a tight two-minute package.

You might still have Escapee or Heart It Races on your playlists — now it's time to get reacquainted with It'5! — a sugar hit you won't regret.

Dan Condon

The Bravery — An Honest Mistake (#48)

An Honest Mistake would be the first and last time The Bravery made the Hottest 100. (Supplied: Island/UMG)

YouTube | Spotify | Apple Music

I can still recall this tune's chorus — heck, even this NYC band's solid self-titled album and its cover! But I imagine for most folks, An Honest Mistake would simply trigger reactions of 'oh yeah, those guys…'

Springing up in the wake of The Killers's breakthrough debut album Hot Fuss, The Bravery hewed so closely to the same new wave inspired indie rock sound that Killers frontman Brandon Flowers accused them of ripping him off.

"They're signed because we're a band," Flowers told MTV at the time. "I can see The Strokes play [and] it's real, and I haven't gotten that from The Bravery. I think people will see through them."

His trash-talking sparked a feudal back-and-forth with The Bravery's Morrissey-but-make-it-punk singer Sam Endicott. It's safe to say The Killers won the war.

The Bravery stopped releasing records by the end of the 2010s. Though they did play a one-off reunion show in 2021 alongside, strangely, Tame Impala, with a set featuring, stranger still, covers of Fugazi, Descendents and Black Flag.

Al Newstead

Little Birdy — Six Months In A Leaky Boat (#96)

Six Months In A Leaky Boat was also the b-side of Little Birdy's Come On Come On single.

YouTube | Spotify | Apple Music

We were still a little way off from the dominance of Like A Versions, but one particular set of covers proved very popular in the 2005 countdown.

We know you haven't forgotten Little Birdy. The band are Hottest 100 royalty and the mid 2000s was when they were really at the height of their powers.

Some people may, however, have forgotten She Will Have Her Way, a tribute to Neil and Tim Finn that had a bit of an impact of the Hottest 100 of 2005.

Little Birdy gave us a faithful take on the Split Enz classic, retaining its energy and idiosyncrasies while putting their own sonic stamp on things.

Katy Steele is outstanding out the front, the perfect voice to nail those incredibly high notes while her band deftly navigate the tricky arrangement.

With Split Enz reforming for shows in 2026, there's no better time to reacquaint yourself with this version. And it's part of the newly reformed band's setlist

Dan Condon

Emiliana Torrini — Sunny Road (#44)

milana Torrini's fourth album, Fisherman's Woman managed to crack the ARIA top 100. (Supplied: Rough Trade)

YouTube | Spotify | Apple Music

Personally, this was a case of a pleasurable refresher, largely because my mother was a fan (shout out Trish)!

Framed as a letter to a lost lover, Sunny Road is a whimsical slice of folk where guitar and keys swirl around Torrini's soft voice yet staunch lyrics. 'I never married, never had those kids / I loved too many, now heaven's closed it gates," she sings. "Some things don't change, my middle name's still 'risk'".

It remains the Icelandic singer-songwriter's most popular song (alongside Jungle Drum) but turns out she's got a fascinating wrap sheet.

A member of Reykjavík electronic collective GusGus before going solo, Torrini won an Ivor Novello Award for co-writing Kylie Minogue's slinky 2003 hit Slow. That was a year after she sang Gollum's Song for movie blockbuster The Lord of the Rings: The Towers.

Her fourth album Fisherwoman's Woman, from which Sunny Road is lifted, was produced by Dan Carey — the esteemed UK producer best known for manning records for Fontaines D.C., Wet Leg, Black Midi, Squid and others. The more you know!

Al Newstead

Scissor Sisters — Filthy/Gorgeous (#83)

The eponymous Scissor Sisters album cracked the top 10 in the Australian ARIA Album Charts. (Supplied: Polydor)

YouTube | Spotify | Apple Music

There was a time it was difficult to escape these glam rock revivalists. Singles like the Elton John-adjacent hoedown Take Your Mama, for instance, or the discoteque rework of Pink Floyd's Comfortably Numb that caught everyone's attention to begin with.

However, Filthy/Gorgeous is a deeper cut from the group's debut album that might've slipped you by. It might not be as memorable, but it's got all the Scissor Sister hallmarks — the Bee Gees falsetto of Jake Shears, irreverent pop lyricism, and throbbing disco groove (that recalls, of all things, Super Mario Bros.)

Al Newstead

The Butterfly Effect — Phoenix (#33)

Phoenix never made a Butterfly Effect album but its their second-highest ever charting in the Hottest 100. (Supplied: The Butterfly Effect) ]

YouTube | Spotify | Apple Music

Prog-leaning Australian hard rock was really having a moment in 2005, as evidenced by several Hottest 100 entries. Perth had Karnivool. Byron Bay had J Award nominees COG. And Brisbane? They had The Butterfly Effect.

Now, I can remember triple j spinning their Deftones-esque 2001 song The Cell. And even 2003 debut album Begins Here. But apologies, it's a complete blur after that. Phoenix was a B-side and later live fan fave that missed out making the tracklist for the band's next album (Imago, 2006).

It holds up okay in 2025, even if the rap-rock backing grunts feel very time-and-place. Despite The Butterfly Effect remaining active, Phoenix hasn't appeared in a setlist since 2018 — so much for a 'rising from the ashes' rebirth.

Al Newstead

Hear the Hottest 100 of 2005 replayed on Double J on Sunday 25 January.

title: James triumphs as Aussie barely misses bobsled history in Milan-Cortina build-up
text:
Bree Walker has just missed out on making history in Germany as she came close to becoming the first Australian ever to win a Crystal Globe as the season's top bobsledder.

Meanwhile in Switzerland, Scotty James reigned supreme at a favourite venue to win the last World Cup halfpipe event before the Olympics, where he'll be seeking an elusive gold medal.

On a big day for Australian Olympic hopes, James sent a clear message to Olympic rivals as he won the Laax Open for a third consecutive time and fifth time in total, while young countryman Valentino Guseli was third.

The 31-year-old James scored 98.75 points for his spectacular second run to claim victory ahead of Kiwi surprise packet Campbell Melville Ives (91.00) and Calgary World Cup winner Guseli (80.25) — the first Oceania podium sweep in FIS history.

Scotty James came out on top in his last event before the Milan-Cortina Games. (FIS Snowboard: David Tributsch)

The thumping win was a big boost for four-time Olympian James, who will be aiming to better the bronze medal he won in Pyeongchang 2018 and silver in Beijing in 2022 at next months Milan-Cortina Olympics.

He has kept a low profile in recent weeks as rivals shared World Cup wins.

"I've been working on some things and this year is a tough year. It's an amazing competition," said James.

"We had two Aussies and a Kiwi on the podium which is unbelievable. The Japanese are riding amazing so you've got to put your best foot forward this year to get a sniff of the podium … I'm pumped.

On a day when the country's winter sports stars continued to look good with the Milan-Cortina Olympics just round the corner, snowboard cross riders Josie Baff and Adam Lambert also both won medals in China to shoot to the top of the World Cup standings.

In Germany, 33-year-old Walker took silver behind Kaillie Humphries in the final World Cup monobob race of the season in Altenberg to wrap up second place for the season.

It was just not quite enough to secure her the overall World Cup triumph, as German Laura Nolte took the seasonal crown by just 17 points.

In the last race before the Olympic showdown in Cortina next month, Walker had to overturn a 27-point deficit on double world monobob champ Nolte to take the Crystal Globe.

She defeated the German, who finished third, 0.06 seconds behind the Aussie after their two runs, but fell just short of leapfrogging Nolte in the final standings.

Bree Walker (left) came close but couldn't quite run down Laura Nolte (middle) in the last event. (Getty Images: Robert Michael)

Humphries, America's reigning Olympic champ, won in a combined 1minute 58.97 seconds for the two runs, 0.13 seconds ahead of Walker (1:59.10) and 0.19 quicker than Nolte.

The great news for Walker, though, is that she is in fine shape to attack for historic gold at the Winter Games after the best World Cup season ever by an Australian sledder, in which she won three races in Lillehammer, Sigulda and St Moritz.

Meanwhile, at the Chinese winter resort of Dongbeiya, Baff took silver in the women's final and Lambert bronze in the men's event.

The pals from Jindabyne in the NSW Snowy Mountains have now moved into top place in their World Cup standings, earning them the coveted yellow leader's bibs.

"It absolutely does feel like an honour," said Lambert. "Obviously, just two races into the season anything can happen, but for now I will savour the feeling and to do it at the same time as Josie, who was my neighbour for most of my childhood, is a special privilege."

Behind Britain's Charlotte Bankes in the big final, Baff grabbed silver in a blanket finish between the other three riders to take the 16th World Cup podium place of her career.

In the men's final, 28-year-old Lambert was able to earn an eighth World Cup podium as he finished behind Austrian Jakob Dusek and Canada's Eliot Grondin.

AAP

title: Australian Open LIVE 2026: Aussie Gibson triumphs; Walton faces Alcaraz hurdle; Sabalenka, Zverev in action
text:
It’s people as far as the eye can see at the Olympic Boulevard gate, with thousands of fans waiting to enter Melbourne Park for the first day of matches.

Attendees seem slightly confused about which direction they should walk to join the back of the queue.

Tennis fans face a long wait to get in. Credit: Chris Hopkins

All ticketholders — regardless of whether they have a ground pass or a stadium pass — are in a single queue that’s ten people wide, and reaches well past John Cain Arena and towards AAMI Park.

There’s also the express entry line, but it isn’t much better.

That queue stretches around a corner and continues to run parallel with the Yarra.

Both lines would be at least a few hundred metres long. One couple about halfway along the queue said they’d been waiting more than 45 minutes.

“It’s not good enough… considering the price of the ticket,” they said.“[Tennis Australia] will probably need to have a crisis management meeting after this … they can’t do this for 14 days.”
